"The greatest trouble with this
country today is that people no longer have the capacity of indignation," declared Arthur Garfield
Hays, one of America's prominent
criminal lawyers, before the student assembly yesterday, discussing his topic, "Martyrs of Injustice."
Mr. Hays called attention to
great injustices perpetrated by our
courts today, "not intentionally, because I am convinced that the
juries are sincere, but because human nature is naturally effected
through its emotions and not by
the facts in a case."

Was indicted because of having
Written a pamphlet relative to sex
matters claimed to be obscene, Mr.
Hays charged the court which convicted her as typifying the "modern tendency to cover up and to
fear the open discussion of this
subject."
Again, he pointed out, when an
article written by H. L. Mencken
Was declared immoral, a jury of
liberally-disposed Bostonians acquitted him, but across the river in
Cambridge, a Greek news vender
was convicted for having sold Mr.
Mencken's article on the grounds
of its alleged obscenity. This case,
he declared, served to illustrate the
large part which personal opinion
and emotion play in the decision of
a case.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
In the January issue of the Hopkins
Blue Jay there appeared a sketch entitled
The Menckens at Home by H. B. Y. and
C. G. It was an exceedingly clever piece
of work, and those of us who have
grown accustomed to the sterile level of
the Jay in the past, prayed fervently
that the two capable men who had created it would continue their good work.
Naturally we were a bit curious. We
wanted to know the names of the men
hiding behind the initials H. B. Y. and
C. G. The editorial page of the Jay informed us that they were Harold B.
Yudkin and one, Chaparral Gould.
The virtues of the first are well known
on the campus. The odor of his "sanctity
rises up to high heaven." But Chaparral
Gould is an unknown. He had never been
heard of before. Nor would Mr. Yudkin
disclose the identity of his collaborator.
So we had to sit back and wait expectantly for another piece from this incomparable team of humorists.
What was our surprise, therefore, to
find that College Humor recently republished a sketch entitled The Menckens t
Home—with credit given to the Stanford
Chaparral. We were incensed! .An irreparable oversight—no, an insult! The
Blue Jay had been slighted. Harold Yudkin immediately became a martyr.
But a careful comparison of the two
sketches disclosed not only startling similarities, but also startling differences.
Obviously, either the men on the Jay
had plagiarized those in the Chaparral,
or thpse in the Chaparral had plagiarized
the men on the Jay.
The most damning evidence, however,
came into our hands when it was pointed
out that the Chaparral number containing The Menckens at Home had proceed the Blue Jay number—The Chaparral had appeared in October, the Jay in
January. What was more, a letter received from the editor of the Stanford
Chaparral — whose name, strangely
enough, is Burnell Gould, (Chaparral
Gould?), writes: "I can throw plenty of
light on this matter, and do so with
great glee. It is one of the clearest cases
of plagiarism anybody ever saw. It might
be griping were it not so obvious. Please
feel that I am vastly amused and not
peeved. I do not thank H. B. Y. and C.
G. for the ending they tacked on."
TORQUEMADA.
The matter rests at this point. Will
Mr. Yudkin step forward and explain
his martyrdom.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
In the January issue of the Hopkins
Blue Jay there appeared a sketch entitled
The Menckens at Home by H. B. Y. and
C. G. It was an exceedingly clever piece
of work, and those of us who have
grown accustomed to the sterile level of
the Jay in the past, prayed fervently
that the two capable men who had created it would continue their good work.
Naturally we were a bit curious. We
wanted to know the names of the men
hiding behind the initials H. B. Y. and
C. G. The editorial page of the Jay informed us that they were Harold B.
Yudkin and one, Chaparral Gould.
The virtues of the first are well known
on the campus. The odor of his "sanctity
rises up to high heaven." But Chaparral
Gould is an unknown. He had never been
heard of before. Nor would Mr. Yudkin
disclose the identity of his collaborator.
So we had to sit back and wait expectantly for another piece from this incomparable team of humorists.
What was our surprise, therefore, to
find that College Humor recently republished a sketch entitled The Menckens t
Home—with credit given to the Stanford
Chaparral. We were incensed! .An irreparable oversight—no, an insult! The
Blue Jay had been slighted. Harold Yudkin immediately became a martyr.
But a careful comparison of the two
sketches disclosed not only startling similarities, but also startling differences.
Obviously, either the men on the Jay
had plagiarized those in the Chaparral,
or thpse in the Chaparral had plagiarized
the men on the Jay.
The most damning evidence, however,
came into our hands when it was pointed
out that the Chaparral number containing The Menckens at Home had proceed the Blue Jay number—The Chaparral had appeared in October, the Jay in
January. What was more, a letter received from the editor of the Stanford
Chaparral — whose name, strangely
enough, is Burnell Gould, (Chaparral
Gould?), writes: "I can throw plenty of
light on this matter, and do so with
great glee. It is one of the clearest cases
of plagiarism anybody ever saw. It might
be griping were it not so obvious. Please
feel that I am vastly amused and not
peeved. I do not thank H. B. Y. and C.
G. for the ending they tacked on."
TORQUEMADA.
The matter rests at this point. Will
Mr. Yudkin step forward and explain
his martyrdom.
